questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with an adnexal mass. Investigations show: CA-125: Slightly raised CA19-9: Normal LDH: Elevated The resected tumor shows the gross and microscopic findings below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dysgerminoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. It is characterized by elevated LDH , occurs in young females , and presents as a solid, lobulated ovarian mass with classic histology (clear cells, central nuclei, fibrous septa with lymphocytes). Tumor markers and histopathology are key to differentiation from epithelial and other germ cell tumors.
  • ➤ Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary. It is characterized by elevated LDH , occurs in young females , and presents as a solid, lobulated ovarian mass with classic histology (clear cells, central nuclei, fibrous septa with lymphocytes).
  • ➤ Dysgerminoma
  • ➤ elevated LDH
  • ➤ young females
  • ➤ solid, lobulated ovarian mass
  • ➤ Tumor markers and histopathology are key to differentiation from epithelial and other germ cell tumors.

questions.text: A 16 French size of Foley's catheter refers to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Outer diameter of 5.3 mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 16 French size of Foley’s catheter refers to the outer diameter of the catheter, which is 5.3mm.

questions.text: Secretin decreases which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gastric secretion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Secretin plays a crucial role in buffering gastric acid in the duodenum by promoting bicarbonate-rich pancreatic and biliary secretions and inhibiting gastric acid production . It helps maintain an optimal pH for enzyme function and intestinal protection.
  • ➤ Secretin plays a crucial role in buffering gastric acid in the duodenum by promoting bicarbonate-rich pancreatic and biliary secretions and inhibiting gastric acid production .
  • ➤ Secretin
  • ➤ bicarbonate-rich pancreatic and biliary secretions
  • ➤ inhibiting gastric acid production
  • ➤ It helps maintain an optimal pH for enzyme function and intestinal protection.

questions.text: Emergency responders document multiple skin discolorations on a patient brought in after being discovered in an abandoned building. The distribution of the lesions raises concerns about possible fabrication of injuries. For medicolegal purposes, it is important to distinguish genuine ecchymosis from artificially applied injuries. Which of the following would be the most reliable clinical clue to help make this distinction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Color changes over time

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Color changes over time are a hallmark of true bruises (ecchymosis) and help differentiate them from artificial lesions, which do not follow a sequential pattern of hemoglobin breakdown.
  • ➤ Color changes over time
  • ➤ true bruises (ecchymosis)
  • ➤ not follow a sequential pattern

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents for evaluation after developing multiple autoimmune manifestations including chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, autoimmune adrenalitis, and hypoparathyroidism. Genetic testing is initiated to determine the molecular basis of the immune dysregulation. Which of the following genes is most directly involved in ensuring central tolerance by allowing the immune system to recognize self-antigens presented in the thymus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) AIRE

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The AIRE gene is responsible for expressing peripheral tissue antigens in the thymus , enabling central tolerance by eliminating self-reactive T cells. Mutations in AIRE impair this process and can lead to widespread autoimmune diseases such as Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1) .
  • ➤ The AIRE gene is responsible for expressing peripheral tissue antigens in the thymus , enabling central tolerance by eliminating self-reactive T cells.
  • ➤ AIRE gene
  • ➤ expressing peripheral tissue antigens in the thymus
  • ➤ Mutations in AIRE impair this process and can lead to widespread autoimmune diseases such as Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1) .
  • ➤ autoimmune diseases
  • ➤ Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1)

questions.text: Which amongst the following is a true statement regarding post term pregnancy? This includes all pregnancies born after 280 days of pregnancy Recognized post term complications include oligohydramnios and fetal macrosomia Amniocentesis should be routinely done to confirm fetal lung maturity prior to induction of labor Initiation of fetal surveillance is recommended after 41 weeks of gestation
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Complications of a post term pregnancy (> 42 weeks) include:
  • ➤ Complications of a post term pregnancy (> 42 weeks) include:

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with progressive memory loss and confusion for 18 months. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes. MMSE score is 22/30. CT brain shows diffuse cortical atrophy and CSF analysis shows low Aβ42 and elevated tau. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alzheimer’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alzheimer’s disease is diagnosed by memory impairment, cortical (especially medial temporal/hippocampal) atrophy, and specific CSF biomarkers.

questions.text: A microbiology lab is working up a case of suspected fungal infection from an immunocompromised patient with oral thrush. A freshly collected specimen is inoculated into serum and incubated at 37°C for 2–3 hours. On microscopic examination, germ tube formation is observed as shown in the image below. This classic finding is diagnostic of which of the following fungal organisms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Candida albicans

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Reynolds-Braude phenomenon, or germ tube test, is a classic diagnostic feature of Candida albicans and helps differentiate it from other non-albicans Candida species.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with long-standing heart failure and atrial fibrillation is started on digoxin for rate control. Which of the following is not a recognized adverse effect of digitalis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Mobitz type II heart block
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mobitz type II heart block

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Digoxin toxicity can cause brady arrhythmias , visual changes , GI upset , and characteristic ECG abnormalities (e.g., PR prolongation, scooped ST segments). However, Mobitz type II AV block is not typical and suggests another etiology.
  • ➤ Digoxin toxicity
  • ➤ brady arrhythmias
  • ➤ visual changes
  • ➤ GI upset
  • ➤ ECG abnormalities
  • ➤ Mobitz type II AV block is not typical

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with irregular menses, hirsutism, and weight gain for 2 years. BMI is 30 kg/m², and BP is 140/90 mmHg. Serum testosterone is 80 ng/dL (normal 15-70), and fasting glucose is 110 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Start oral contraceptive pills and metformin

options.label: B
options.text: Initiate clomiphene citrate and lifestyle modification

options.label: D
options.text: Begin letrozole and weight loss counseling

questions.correct_answer: A. Start oral contraceptive pills and metformin
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Start oral contraceptive pills and metformin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ OCPs and metformin address the core features of PCOS, including hyperandrogenism and insulin resistance.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a known diagnosis of bipolar disorder presents to the outpatient clinic. He acknowledges that he has bipolar disorder and understands his diagnosis completely. However, he has been very noncompliant with his medications, taking them only intermittently. He continues to use recreational drugs on and off despite having experienced multiple relapses triggered by drug use. He is reluctant to see his psychiatrist regularly and often misses appointments. Based on this presentation, what grade of insight does this patient have?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Grade 4 - Intellectual insight

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intellectual insight (Grade 4) represents a critical gap between understanding one's illness and implementing necessary behavioral changes, highlighting why assessment of insight must consider both cognitive awareness and actual behavior.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man reports chest discomfort and shortness of breath. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest reveals an anterior mediastinal mass. The Hounsfield Unit (HU) measurement of the lesion is −70 HU. Based on the radiologic findings and attenuation value, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Teratoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fat-containing anterior mediastinal mass with a Hounsfield Unit near −70 is most suggestive of a mature teratoma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a ruptured spleen following blunt abdominal trauma is taken for emergency laparotomy. On arrival in the OR, his vital signs are: Blood pressure: 80/50 mmHg Heart rate: 125/min He appears pale and diaphoretic. A rapid-acting induction agent is needed. Which of the following is the most appropriate induction agent for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ketamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with hypovolemia and hypotension , ketamine is the induction agent of choice because of its sympathomimetic properties , which help maintain cardiovascular stability during anesthesia.
  • ➤ hypovolemia and hypotension
  • ➤ ketamine
  • ➤ sympathomimetic properties
  • ➤ maintain cardiovascular stability

questions.text: A patient presents with scoliosis. X-ray is shown below. Identify the likely cause:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Congenital

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital curves tend to be sharper and shorter than idiopathic curves.

questions.text: GNP minus capital we consume is known as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) NNP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Net National Product (NNP) is derived by subtracting depreciation (capital consumption) from Gross National Product (GNP) . NNP = GNP – Depreciation .
  • ➤ Net National Product (NNP) is derived by subtracting depreciation (capital consumption) from Gross National Product (GNP) . NNP = GNP – Depreciation .
  • ➤ Net National Product (NNP)
  • ➤ subtracting depreciation
  • ➤ Gross National Product (GNP)
  • ➤ NNP = GNP – Depreciation

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with edema, hypertension, and hematuria for 2 months. He has a history of diabetes and smoking. Serum creatinine is 2.8 mg/dL, and urine protein is 3.5 g/day. Renal biopsy and immunofluorescence is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) ANCA related nephritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis is a common cause of RPGN and requires urgent immunosuppression.

questions.text: Match the Following: Supraglottic Airway Devices Column A (Devices) LMA Supreme LMA Proseal LMA Fastrach Ambu AURA40 Column B (Features) First-generation device Special LMA Single-use second-generation device Multiple-use second-generation device

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with progressive jaundice, pruritus, and dark-colored urine for the past 3 weeks. He denies alcohol use or viral hepatitis. Physical exam reveals scleral icterus and hepatomegaly. Imaging shows a mass at the hepatic duct bifurcation causing biliary obstruction. Biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma of the biliary tract as shown in the image below. Which of the following is incorrect about this tumor?

options.label: B
options.text: Arises from intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.

options.label: C
options.text: Risk factors include infestation by liver flukes, primary sclerosing cholangitis, hepatolithiasis and fibropolycystic liver disease.

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Very good prognosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholangiocarcinoma, though the second most common primary hepatic malignancy, typically carries a poor prognosis due to late diagnosis and aggressive local spread, making early recognition and intervention critical.

questions.text: A patient has a blood pressure reading of 130/85 mmHg. What is the approximate mean arterial pressure (MAP)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 100 mmHg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MAP reflects the perfusion pressure experienced by organs. It is crucial in assessing organ perfusion , especially in shock or hypotension. A MAP of ≥65 mmHg is generally considered necessary for adequate tissue perfusion in critically ill patients.
  • ➤ MAP reflects the perfusion pressure experienced by organs.
  • ➤ MAP
  • ➤ perfusion pressure
  • ➤ It is crucial in assessing organ perfusion , especially in shock or hypotension.
  • ➤ organ perfusion
  • ➤ A MAP of ≥65 mmHg is generally considered necessary for adequate tissue perfusion in critically ill patients.
  • ➤ ≥65 mmHg

questions.text: A 40-year-old female from Bihar presents with fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance for 6 months. She has a history of delivery complicated by hypotension that required multiple blood transfusions 5 years ago. TSH is 0.1 mIU/L, free T4 0.6 ng/dL, and prolactin is low. The thyroid ultrasound reveals a small, hypoechoic gland. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sheehan’s syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sheehan’s syndrome should be suspected in hypothyroidism with a history of postpartum hemorrhage in India.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) undergoes argon laser trabeculoplasty to help reduce intraocular pressure and limit the need for multiple medications. Shortly after the procedure, he develops a sudden rise in intraocular pressure (IOP). Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this complication?

options.label: A
options.text: Corneal edema caused by laser energy absorption

options.label: B
options.text: Inflammatory debris blocking the trabecular meshwork

options.label: C
options.text: Ciliary body inflammation reducing aqueous outflow

options.label: D
options.text: Damage to Schlemm’s canal causing impaired drainage

questions.correct_answer: B. Inflammatory debris blocking the trabecular meshwork
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inflammatory debris blocking the trabecular meshwork

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Following laser trabeculoplasty, a transient rise in IOP may occur due to inflammatory debris or pigment blocking the trabecular meshwork. Pretreatment with IOP-lowering agents and anti-inflammatory drops can help prevent this.
  • ➤ Following laser trabeculoplasty, a transient rise in IOP may occur due to inflammatory debris or pigment blocking the trabecular meshwork.
  • ➤ Pretreatment with IOP-lowering agents and anti-inflammatory drops can help prevent this.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with vaginal spotting and lower abdominal pain. Transvaginal ultrasound shows no intrauterine or extrauterine gestational sac. Her serum β-hCG is 700 mIU/mL. What is the current diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pregnancy of unknown location

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pregnancy of unknown location (PUL) is diagnosed when no intra- or extrauterine sac is visible and serum β-hCG is below the discriminatory threshold; serial β-hCG and repeat ultrasound are required for clarification.
  • ➤ Pregnancy of unknown location (PUL) is diagnosed when no intra- or extrauterine sac is visible and serum β-hCG is below the discriminatory threshold; serial β-hCG and repeat ultrasound are required for clarification.
  • ➤ Pregnancy of unknown location (PUL)

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of chronic constipation and antipsychotics use, presents with severe abdominal pain, distension and obstipation for the past 24 hours. Examination reveals a markedly distended and tympanic abdomen. Imaging shows a bent inner tube sign. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CECT abdomen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CECT abdomen , as it helps confirm diagnosis and evaluate complications in the absence of endoscopy. While colonoscopic decompression is definitive , it’s not one of the options given , and CECT provides the safest, next best step in this context.
  • ➤ CECT abdomen , as it helps confirm diagnosis and evaluate complications in the absence of endoscopy.
  • ➤ CECT abdomen
  • ➤ While colonoscopic decompression is definitive , it’s not one of the options given , and CECT provides the safest, next best step in this context.
  • ➤ colonoscopic decompression is definitive
  • ➤ not one of the options given
  • ➤ safest, next best step

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was admitted for a large abdominal swelling. A clinical diagnosis of splenomegaly was made. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The spleen is situated in the upper left quadrant of the abdomen beneath the diaphragm

options.label: B
options.text: The long axis of the spleen lies along the 10th rib

options.label: C
options.text: A pathologically enlarged spleen extends downward and forward, toward the left iliac fossa

options.label: D
options.text: The spleen has a notched anterior border caused by incomplete fusion of its parts during development

questions.correct_answer: C. A pathologically enlarged spleen extends downward and forward, toward the left iliac fossa
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A pathologically enlarged spleen extends downward and forward, toward the left iliac fossa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The spleen lies in the left upper quadrant , aligned along the 10th rib , and has a notched anterior border due to its embryological origin. While splenomegaly may clinically appear to extend into the left iliac fossa , the phrenicocolic ligament restricts its downward expansion , making this a misleading but anatomically incorrect statement .
  • ➤ The spleen lies in the left upper quadrant , aligned along the 10th rib , and has a notched anterior border due to its embryological origin.
  • ➤ left upper quadrant
  • ➤ 10th rib
  • ➤ notched anterior border
  • ➤ While splenomegaly may clinically appear to extend into the left iliac fossa , the phrenicocolic ligament restricts its downward expansion , making this a misleading but anatomically incorrect statement .
  • ➤ splenomegaly
  • ➤ left iliac fossa
  • ➤ phrenicocolic ligament
  • ➤ downward expansion
  • ➤ misleading but anatomically incorrect statement

questions.text: Patient presented with Paresthesia and loss of sensation over lower part of deltoid. X-ray showed fracture surgical neck of humerus. Likely nerve to be involved is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Axillary nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Given the location of the fracture (surgical neck of the humerus) and the specific symptoms (paresthesia and loss of sensation over the lower part of the deltoid), the Axillary nerve is overwhelmingly the most likely nerve to be involved due to its close anatomical relationship to this bone region and its sensory supply to the very area described.
  • ➤ Axillary nerve

questions.text: Assertion (A): Vigabatrin can cause visual field loss. Reason (R): Vigabatrin inhibits GABA transaminase.

options.label: A
options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A

options.label: B
options.text: Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A

options.label: C
options.text: A is true, but R is false

options.label: D
options.text: A is false, but R is true

questions.correct_answer: A. Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vigabatrin can cause visual field loss because it inhibits GABA transaminase, increasing GABA levels and contributing to retinal neurotoxicity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is being evaluated for suspected secondary syphilis. His VDRL test returns negative, but the clinical suspicion remains high due to symptoms and risk factors. A repeat test on a diluted serum sample returns positive. This discrepancy is most likely explained by which of the following immunological phenomena?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prozone phenomenon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Prozone phenomenon refers to a false-negative serological test result due to antibody excess, which prevents visible reaction; dilution of the sample can restore test accuracy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a skin biopsy showing disruption of cell-to-cell adhesion within a specific layer of the epidermis. The biopsy highlights a layer of polygonal cells with desmosomal bridges. Which layer of the epidermis demonstrates the most prominent desmosomes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Layer C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Stratum spinosum is the epidermal layer with the most prominent desmosomes . These intercellular connections provide mechanical strength and are essential for epidermal integrity. Desmosomal disruption can result in blistering diseases like pemphigus vulgaris .
  • ➤ The Stratum spinosum is the epidermal layer with the most prominent desmosomes .
  • ➤ Stratum spinosum
  • ➤ most prominent desmosomes
  • ➤ These intercellular connections provide mechanical strength and are essential for epidermal integrity.
  • ➤ Desmosomal disruption can result in blistering diseases like pemphigus vulgaris .
  • ➤ pemphigus vulgaris

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of a persistent lump in her right breast. She first noticed the lump 3 months ago, and it has progressively increased in size. questions.text: A 9-year-old boy from a remote Indian village is brought to the community health center with complaints of brown staining and pitting of the upper front teeth. The history reveals the child has been drinking groundwater from a local well since infancy. Based on this, what is the expected nutrient level in the drinking water from the well?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) > 1.5 ppm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dental fluorosis occurs when fluoride levels in drinking water exceed 1.5 ppm , especially during tooth development. Brown staining and pitting are common signs. This threshold is crucial for community health assessments involving groundwater safety.
  • ➤ Dental fluorosis occurs when fluoride levels in drinking water exceed 1.5 ppm , especially during tooth development.
  • ➤ Dental fluorosis
  • ➤ exceed 1.5 ppm
  • ➤ Brown staining and pitting are common signs. This threshold is crucial for community health assessments involving groundwater safety.

questions.text: Ketogenesis is biochemical reaction in which ketone bodies are synthesized in the liver through the degradation of free fatty acids and ketogenic amino acids. Which statement about ketogenesis is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Ketone bodies are utilized by hepatocytes

options.label: B
options.text: Ketogenesis occurs in the mitochondria of hepatocytes

options.label: C
options.text: Ketosis can deplete the alkali reserve

options.label: D
options.text: Ketogenesis is exaggerated in diabetes mellitus and prolonged starvation. It is termed as Ketosis

questions.correct_answer: A. Ketone bodies are utilized by hepatocytes
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatocytes cannot utilize ketone bodies due to lack of the enzyme thiophorase; hence, while ketogenesis occurs in liver mitochondria, the synthesized ketone bodies are exported for use by extrahepatic tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes this type of flap?

options.text: It is a type of osseomyocutaneous flap

options.label: C
options.text: Blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected

options.label: D

  • ➤ isolating, disconnecting, and reattaching the vascular supply using microsurgery

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with restricted wrist movements following a fall. Radiographic examination shows no fractures, but joint integrity appears intact. Which type of joint is primarily responsible for the wrist's restricted movement?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ellipsoid joint

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding monozygotic twin formation are true? If division occurs after embryonic disc formation, it results in conjoined twins. If division occurs before 72 hours, it results in diamniotic–dichorionic twins. If division occurs between 4–8 days, it results in monochorionic–monoamniotic twins. If division occurs after 8 days, it results in monochorionic–monoamniotic twins
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The timing of embryonic division determines the type of placentation and amniotic sac configuration in monozygotic twinning. Early division (≤3 days) leads to dichorionic-diamniotic twins, intermediate division (4–7 days) to monochorionic-diamniotic, late division (8–12 days) to monochorionic-monoamniotic, and very late division (>13 days) to conjoined twins.
  • ➤ The timing of embryonic division determines the type of placentation and amniotic sac configuration in monozygotic twinning.
  • ➤ Early division (≤3 days) leads to dichorionic-diamniotic twins, intermediate division (4–7 days) to monochorionic-diamniotic, late division (8–12 days) to monochorionic-monoamniotic, and very late division (>13 days) to conjoined twins.

questions.text: A pediatric epidemiologist is analyzing a dataset of neonatal birth weights. The current summary statistics are as follows: Mean: 2.8 kg Median: 3.0 kg Mode: 3.2 kg After data entry from a remote neonatal unit, several infants with extremely low birth weights (e.g., <1.5 kg) are added to the dataset. Which of the following is the most likely consequence on the distribution of birth weights?

options.label: A
options.text: The mean will increase, shifting the distribution to the right

options.label: C
options.text: The mean will decrease more than the median, creating left skewness

options.label: D
options.text: The mode will increase, indicating improved population health

questions.correct_answer: C. The mean will decrease more than the median, creating left skewness
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The mean will decrease more than the median, creating left skewness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In skewed distributions, the mean is pulled in the direction of the tail. When extremely low values are added to a dataset, the mean decreases more than the median, resulting in a left-skewed (negatively skewed) distribution. Outliers affect the mean more than the median. The presence of extreme low values causes left skewness, where mean < median < mode. This pattern helps in identifying data distortion due to outliers.
  • ➤ In skewed distributions, the mean is pulled in the direction of the tail.
  • ➤ When extremely low values are added to a dataset, the mean decreases more than the median, resulting in a left-skewed (negatively skewed) distribution.
  • ➤ Outliers affect the mean more than the median.
  • ➤ The presence of extreme low values causes left skewness, where mean < median < mode. This pattern helps in identifying data distortion due to outliers.

questions.text: A medical officer at a hospital is evaluating a patient with electrocution. The individual has no detectable pulse or breathing, but their body is warm, and pupils are reactive to light. Which of the following best describes this condition?

Electrocution is a known cause where this can occur, as the electrical current can disrupt the heart's rhythm and breathing without immediately causing irreversible cellular death, especially if the body remains warm and the brain still shows some reflexes (like pupillary reactivity).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is hospitalized for treatment of sepsis and receives intravenous antibiotics and fluids. Two days later, he develops oliguria. Labs reveal: BUN: 42 mg/dL Creatinine: 3.0 mg/dL BUN:Cr ratio < 15 FENa > 2% Urine osmolality < 500 mOsm/kg Urine microscopy shows brown granular casts. Which of the following best explains the mechanism of his renal dysfunction?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypoperfusion of kidneys causing increased BUN reabsorption

options.label: C
options.text: Necrotic tubular epithelial cell obstruction reducing GFR

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Necrotic tubular epithelial cell obstruction reducing GFR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is an intrarenal cause of acute kidney injury, characterized by necrotic tubular cells obstructing the nephron, leading to decreased GFR, muddy brown casts, low BUN:Cr ratio, and impaired urine concentrating ability.

questions.text: A young adult female presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of food over several weeks. She has a known history of iron deficiency anemia diagnosed 3 months ago. A barium swallow is the imaging modality of choice, and early recognition is essential due to its association with increased risk of esophageal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 42-year-old sheep farmer from Central Europe presents with right upper quadrant discomfort and mild hepatomegaly. questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after experiencing sudden vision loss in his right eye shortly following an elective eye procedure. Investigation confirms that the intervention was mistakenly performed on the right eye instead of the scheduled left eye. As legal proceedings are initiated for medical negligence, the court applies the doctrine of res ipsa loquitur due to the nature of the error. In such a scenario, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the burden of proof?

options.label: A
options.text: Burden of proof lies on the surgeon to demonstrate absence of negligence in performing surgery on the wrong eye

options.label: B
options.text: Burden of proof lies on the patient to establish that surgeon’s actions caused vision loss

options.label: C
options.text: Burden of proof lies on both the patient and surgeon equally as contributory negligence applies

options.label: D
options.text: Burden of proof lies solely on the patient to show that the wrong eye was operated on

questions.correct_answer: A. Burden of proof lies on the surgeon to demonstrate absence of negligence in performing surgery on the wrong eye
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Burden of proof lies on the surgeon to demonstrate absence of negligence in performing surgery on the wrong eye

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In obvious medical errors such as wrong-site surgery , the doctrine of res ipsa loquitur applies, shifting the burden of proof onto the healthcare provider to demonstrate lack of negligence .
  • ➤ wrong-site surgery
  • ➤ doctrine of res ipsa loquitur
  • ➤ burden of proof onto the healthcare provider
  • ➤ lack of negligence

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with lethargy and generalized edema. questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Alpha-1 antitrypsin (A1AT) deficiency is/are incorrect? It is an autosomal recessive condition that can cause both liver and lung disease. questions.text: A 26-year-old contact lens wearer presents to the ophthalmology clinic with painful, red eyes, blurred vision, and photophobia. Slit-lamp examination reveals a ring-shaped corneal ulcer. Corneal scrapings are taken, and laboratory analysis identifies a free-living amoeba with characteristic double-walled cysts. Which of the following organisms is the most likely causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acanthamoeba castellanii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acanthamoeba castellanii is a free-living amoeba that causes keratitis in contact lens users and can be identified by its characteristic double-walled cysts in corneal samples.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is undergoing immunological workup following repeated respiratory infections and progressive gait instability. Clinical examination reveals telangiectatic lesions over the sclerae. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and significant immunoglobulin profile abnormalities. One immunoglobulin subtype is notably absent on testing. Which of the following immunoglobulin classes is characteristically absent in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IgA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Ataxia telangiectasia, the immunoglobulin class that is characteristically absent is IgA, contributing to recurrent mucosal infections and helping in diagnostic confirmation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with progressive cognitive decline and intermittent headaches. MRI of the brain is performed to evaluate the cause. One of the axial images is shown below. Based on the grayscale pattern of signal intensities and the structures highlighted, which of the following MRI sequences most likely corresponds to the image shown?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Proton density weighted image

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A proton density (PD) weighted MRI provides high anatomical detail with subtle contrast, useful for identifying fine structural changes. It is recognized by clear gray-white matter distinction , minimal CSF brightness , and absence of the strong T1 or T2 signal characteristics.
  • ➤ A proton density (PD) weighted MRI provides high anatomical detail with subtle contrast, useful for identifying fine structural changes.

  • ➤ minimal CSF brightness

questions.text: A screening test has 90% sensitivity and 90% specificity. In a population where disease prevalence is 20%, what is the Positive Predictive Value (PPV) of the test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 69.2%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Positive Predictive Value (PPV) increases with higher disease prevalence , and depends on both sensitivity and specificity .

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding rheumatic heart disease is/are incorrect? Vegetations are small, warty, and usually located along the line of valve closure. Mitral valve is the most commonly affected, often in combination with the aortic valve. Vegetations are large, friable, and loosely attached, typically leading to septic emboli. Microscopic examination reveals fibrin and platelet thrombi with mononuclear cell infiltration. Aschoff bodies may be seen in the underlying endocardium as a feature of rheumatic carditis.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rheumatic heart disease features small, firmly attached vegetations along the valve closure line, primarily affecting the mitral valve, with mononuclear infiltrates and Aschoff bodies microscopically. Large, friable vegetations are characteristic of infective endocarditis, not rheumatic disease.
  • ➤ Rheumatic heart disease features small, firmly attached vegetations along the valve closure line, primarily affecting the mitral valve, with mononuclear infiltrates and Aschoff bodies microscopically.
  • ➤ Large, friable vegetations are characteristic of infective endocarditis, not rheumatic disease.

questions.text: A middle-aged adult undergoes evaluation for a biopsy-proven malignancy located in the lower rectum. Imaging shows no distant metastasis. It enables precise dissection from a transanal approach , improving oncologic and functional outcomes in rectal cancer management.
  • ➤ taTME (Transanal Total Mesorectal Excision) is a specialized, minimally invasive surgical technique used for the treatment of rectal cancers , especially in challenging pelvic anatomy.

  • ➤ oncologic and functional outcomes

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents with refractory bleeding and elevated PT/INR after accidentally ingesting rat poison. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology behind his bleeding?

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibition of synthesis of γ-carboxylated clotting factors

questions.correct_answer: C. Inhibition of synthesis of γ-carboxylated clotting factors
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inhibition of synthesis of γ-carboxylated clotting factors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rodenticides like brodifacoum inhibit vitamin K–dependent γ-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, leading to prolonged PT/INR and life-threatening bleeding . The antidote is vitamin K₁ , and severe cases may require FFP or PCC (prothrombin complex concentrate).
  • ➤ brodifacoum
  • ➤ vitamin K–dependent γ-carboxylation
  • ➤ prolonged PT/INR and life-threatening bleeding
  • ➤ vitamin K₁
  • ➤ FFP or PCC

questions.text: In the hypoxic tissues, which of the following metabolites is most likely to accumulate as the major end product of glucose metabolism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lactate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Under anaerobic or hypoxic conditions, glucose metabolism results in lactate accumulation due to the conversion of pyruvate to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with difficulty swallowing, hoarseness of voice, restlessness, and a history of being bitten by a stray dog 2 weeks ago. Neurological examination reveals signs consistent with encephalitis. Rabies is suspected based on clinical features and history. Which of the following is the most sensitive method for confirming the diagnosis of rabies in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Viral RNA detection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Detection of viral RNA by RT-PCR is the most sensitive method for diagnosing rabies in a symptomatic patient, especially early in the course of illness.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with palpitations, fatigue, and occasional syncope for 2 weeks. She has a history of hypertension and hypothyroidism. The ECG is shown below. questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who is 5 weeks pregnant presents to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain and signs of shock. She reports that her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. On physical examination, she has tenderness in the lower abdomen, particularly in the right adnexal region. A Doppler ultrasound shows the following appearance in the right adnexa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tubal gestation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "ring of fire" sign on Doppler ultrasound, in the setting of early pregnancy with acute abdominal pain and shock, is highly suggestive of tubal ectopic pregnancy . This condition requires urgent diagnosis and management to prevent complications such as tubal rupture and hemorrhagic shock.
  • ➤ The "ring of fire" sign on Doppler ultrasound, in the setting of early pregnancy with acute abdominal pain and shock, is highly suggestive of tubal ectopic pregnancy .

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought with a history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. The child is irritable and drinks water eagerly. Eyes are sunken and skin pinch retracts in 2 seconds. What treatment is advised?

options.label: A
options.text: Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger signs develop.

options.label: B
options.text: Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same.

options.label: C
options.text: Consider severe dehydration and start IV fluids, IV antibiotics and refer.

questions.correct_answer: A. Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger signs develop.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is evaluated for a history of frequent nosebleeds and easy bruising since early childhood. He recently experienced prolonged bleeding following a minor dental procedure. Laboratory tests reveal. Platelet count: mildly reduced Bleeding time: prolonged Platelet morphology: giant platelets Platelet aggregation studies: abnormal response to ristocetin, but normal aggregation with ADP and collagen Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bernard-Soulier syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a platelet adhesion disorder due to GPIb deficiency, characterized by giant platelets, thrombocytopenia, and absent ristocetin-induced aggregation.

questions.text: Which type of amyloidosis is most likely to develop in a patient undergoing long-term hemodialysis due to chronic renal failure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Amyloid β2 microglobulin (Aβ2M)

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman delivered her first baby 3 days ago through normal vaginal delivery. Initially, after delivery, she appeared withdrawn with frequent crying spells and sadness of mood. Today, her husband reports that she has been claiming that their baby has been swapped with someone else's child and refuses to breastfeed. She has been observed muttering to herself throughout the day. There is no past history of psychiatric illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Postpartum psychosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postpartum psychosis is basically an episode of bipolar disorder triggered by the stress of childbirth, presenting within 2-3 weeks of delivery with initial mood symptoms progressing to delusions and hallucinations.

questions.text: A patient sustained a hyperextension injury to his knee. Which of the following ligament prevents excess movement of tibia on femur?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anterior cruciate ligament

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) is the primary ligament that prevents excess movement of the femur on the tibia during hyperextension. When the knee extends beyond its normal range, the ACL becomes taut, stopping further backward bending.
  • ➤ The Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) is the primary ligament that prevents excess movement of the femur on the tibia during hyperextension.

questions.text: A 56 years old homeless man presents to ER with increased fatigability and exertional dyspnea. Physical examination shows significant lower extremity edema and decreased sensation over the ankles and feet. Further evaluation reveals cardiac dilation and increased cardiac output. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thiamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiamine deficiency can lead to wet beriberi, characterized by high-output cardiac failure and peripheral neuropathy, especially in malnourished or alcoholic patients.
